content.title: Cardiac Stress Testing
content.summary: Cardiac stress testing evaluates myocardial ischemia by increasing cardiac workload through exercise or pharmacologic stress, combined with ECG monitoring and/or imaging (nuclear, echocardiography, CMR). Test selection depends on baseline ECG interpretability, exercise capacity, and pretest probability of coronary artery disease.
key_points: Exercise treadmill test (ETT) is first-line for patients who can exercise with interpretable ECG
Imaging (nuclear or echo) required if baseline ECG abnormalities (LBBB, LVH, digoxin, WPW, paced rhythm)
Pharmacologic stress (regadenoson, adenosine, dobutamine) for patients unable to exercise adequately
Duke Treadmill Score integrates exercise time, ST depression, and angina for prognosis
Sensitivity ~70% for ETT alone; ~85-90% with imaging; specificity ~75-85%
Absolute contraindications: acute MI <2 days, unstable angina, uncontrolled arrhythmias, severe AS
content.statement: Stress testing is a cornerstone of ischemia evaluation, providing diagnostic and prognostic information. The choice of stress modality (exercise vs pharmacologic) and imaging (none, nuclear, echo, CMR) should be individualized based on patient characteristics, pretest probability, and local expertise.

explanation.intuition: Exercise increases myocardial oxygen demand through elevated heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. In the presence of obstructive CAD, this demand cannot be met, resulting in ischemia manifesting as ST depression, wall motion abnormalities, or perfusion defects. Pharmacologic vasodilators (adenosine) cause differential flow between normal and stenotic vessels (coronary steal), detected by perfusion imaging.
explanation.key_insight: Pre-test probability determines post-test interpretation. In intermediate-probability patients, stress testing adds the most value. In very low (<5%) or very high (>90%) probability patients, testing may not significantly change management. Imaging adds value when ECG is uninterpretable or for localization/extent of ischemia.
explanation.technical_details: Standard Bruce protocol increases speed/grade every 3 minutes. Target HR is 85% of age-predicted maximum (220-age). Adequate workload is >5 METs or >85% MPHR. ST depression ≥1mm horizontal/downsloping 80ms after J-point is positive. Duke Score = exercise time - (5 × ST depression) - (4 × angina index).

definitions_glossary.exercise_treadmill_test: ETT using graded exercise protocol with continuous ECG monitoring for ischemia detection
definitions_glossary.pharmacologic_stress: Use of vasodilators (adenosine, regadenoson, dipyridamole) or inotropes (dobutamine) when exercise not feasible
definitions_glossary.nuclear_stress_test: Myocardial perfusion imaging with Tc-99m or Tl-201 tracers to detect perfusion defects
definitions_glossary.stress_echocardiography: Echo before and after stress to detect new wall motion abnormalities indicating ischemia
definitions_glossary.duke_treadmill_score: Prognostic score combining exercise time, ST depression, and angina; predicts mortality
definitions_glossary.metabolic_equivalents: METs measure workload; 1 MET = resting oxygen consumption; prognostic value
definitions_glossary.chronotropic_incompetence: Failure to achieve 85% age-predicted HR; associated with worse prognosis
definitions_glossary.heart_rate_recovery: HR drop <12 bpm at 1 min post-exercise indicates autonomic dysfunction; poor prognosis
definitions_glossary.reversible_defect: Perfusion defect present on stress but not rest images indicating ischemia
definitions_glossary.fixed_defect: Perfusion defect present on both stress and rest indicating scar/infarction
definitions_glossary.transient_ischemic_dilation: LV cavity appears larger on stress than rest images; marker of severe CAD

pathophysiology.mechanism: Exercise increases HR, BP, and contractility, raising myocardial oxygen demand (MVO2). In normal coronaries, flow increases 4-5 fold. Stenotic arteries cannot augment flow proportionally, creating supply-demand mismatch. Vasodilators cause maximal dilation of normal vessels with minimal effect on stenotic beds (fixed resistance), creating heterogeneous flow detectable by perfusion imaging.
key_pathways: Exercise → increased HR, BP, contractility → increased MVO2
Stenotic arteries → limited flow reserve → ischemia with increased demand
Vasodilators → coronary steal → differential perfusion between territories
Dobutamine → increased contractility/HR → unmasked wall motion abnormalities
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Stress testing provides both diagnostic (presence of CAD) and prognostic (extent, severity) information guiding decisions on revascularization, medical therapy intensification, and lifestyle modification.

positive_ett_criteria.st_depression: ≥1mm horizontal or downsloping at J+80ms in 2+ contiguous leads
positive_ett_criteria.st_elevation: ≥1mm in non-Q wave leads (very specific for transmural ischemia)

adequate_test.duration: Highly variable; >6 min Stage 2 Bruce generally adequate

high_risk_features: ST depression at <5 METs or HR <100
imaging_indications: Baseline ECG abnormalities (LBBB, LVH with repolarization, WPW, paced, digoxin)

test_selection_algorithm.cannot_exercise: Pharmacologic stress (vasodilator nuclear or dobutamine echo)
test_selection_algorithm.lbbb_or_paced: Vasodilator stress nuclear or CMR (not dobutamine due to septal artifact)

pharmacologic_agents.regadenoson: Single bolus A2A agonist; minimal hemodynamic effects; most commonly used
pharmacologic_agents.adenosine: Short-acting vasodilator; requires continuous infusion; bronchospasm risk
pharmacologic_agents.dipyridamole: Adenosine reuptake inhibitor; longer duration; reversible with aminophylline
pharmacologic_agents.dobutamine: Beta-agonist for stress echo; increases HR and contractility

post_test_management.low_risk_negative: Reassurance, risk factor modification, no further testing
post_test_management.intermediate_result: Consider coronary CTA or functional imaging
post_test_management.high_risk_positive: Coronary angiography for consideration of revascularization

skos.definition: A diagnostic procedure that evaluates myocardial ischemia by increasing cardiac workload through exercise or pharmacologic stress while monitoring ECG and/or cardiac imaging

cpt.description: Cardiovascular stress test using maximal or submaximal treadmill
Myocardial perfusion imaging SPECT multiple studies

learning_objectives: Select appropriate stress testing modality based on patient characteristics
Interpret ETT results including ST changes and Duke Treadmill Score
Recognize high-risk stress test features requiring angiography
Identify contraindications to exercise and pharmacologic stress testing
Apply stress test results to clinical decision-making
clinical_pearls: ETT alone sufficient if patient can exercise AND baseline ECG is interpretable
LBBB/paced rhythm → use vasodilator (not dobutamine) due to septal artifact
Duke Score ≤-11 is high risk (annual mortality ~5%); Score ≥+5 is low risk (<1%)
Heart rate recovery <12 bpm at 1 minute is independent predictor of mortality
Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors - hold for 12-24h before vasodilator stress
Reaching 10 METs on exercise without ischemia has excellent prognosis regardless of CAD
common_misconceptions: All patients need imaging with stress (ETT alone adequate for many)
Negative stress test rules out CAD (sensitivity ~70% for ETT)
LBBB can be evaluated with dobutamine stress echo (artifact limits accuracy)
